author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Millions of low-income Americans rely on the food benefit program called SNAP for food amid rising living costs.
42.4 million people, including legal residents, currently receive benefits.
Seventy percent are elderly, disabled, or children, with average aid under $351 per month.
New rules require able-bodied adults 18–64 to work 80 hours monthly or face benefit limits.
States will cover half of federal administration costs from October, adding budget pressures.
Restrictions on purchasing sugary drinks, snacks, and junk food begin January 1 in 18 states.
Officials claim the rules promote health and self-reliance; recipients warn they’ll hurt the vulnerable.

Al Jazeera’s Rosiland Jordan reports from Washington, DC. 

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
Follow us on X: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish
Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera
Check our website: http://www.aljazeera.com/
Check out our Instagram page: https://www.instagram.com/aljazeeraenglish/
title: US Food benefits crisis: Work requirements and restrictions hit hard

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Chile’s presidential palace, bombed during Pinochet’s 1973 coup, is now being repainted ahead of a new far-right president.
Jose Antonio Kast’s election marks the biggest rightward shift since Chile returned to democracy 35 years ago.
This follows a regional trend with right-wing leaders in El Salvador, Ecuador, Argentina, and Honduras.
These leaders, aligned with Trump, promise to tackle crime, migration, and restore conservative values.
Rising corruption and violence make far-right, law-and-order messages appealing to voters seeking practical solutions.
Upcoming elections in Colombia, Brazil, and Peru could extend the rightward shift across South America.
Analysts warn the region must navigate carefully, balancing governance with human rights amid growing US influence.

Al Jazeera’s Lucia Newman reports from Santiago, Chile

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
Follow us on X: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish
Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera
Check
title: Chile’s far-right turn: What it means for Latin America

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Millions of Americans start the new year facing soaring healthcare costs.
Congress failed to extend subsidies that kept insurance premiums lower.
Over 20 million people may struggle to afford necessary medical care.
Since 2013, ACA premiums and deductibles have nearly doubled, while insurers’ profits surged.
Past government support eased costs, but subsidies expired on 1 January.
Republican leadership offers no alternative, while Trump promises reforms repeatedly.
Polling shows growing support for a not-for-profit, government-run healthcare system.

Al Jazeera’s Shihab Rattansi reports from Washington, DC.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
As 2026 begins, Gaza sees little hope or celebration.
Families remain displaced in tents and damaged homes.
Survival, not plans or wishes, is their daily concern.
People struggle with basic needs: shelter, warmth, and safety for children.
Exhaustion lingers after more than two years of violence and destruction.
Entire neighbourhoods have been razed, leaving ongoing misery.
For many Palestinians, the new year is just another day of struggle.

Al Jazeera’s Hani Mahmoud reports from Gaza City.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Al Jazeera has obtained leaked documents and recordings showing former Syrian regime figures plotting to reorganise armed networks.
The files reveal funding channels, weapons stockpiles, and coordination inside Syria and abroad.
The leaks implicate al-Assad’s high-ranking officers, specifically Suheil al-Hassan, the brigadier-general who commanded the notorious Quwwat al-Nimr (Tiger Forces), an elite unit in the former regime’s army.
Documents suggest up to 168,000 fighters remain loyal to former regime networks across Syria.
Audio recordings include Hasan discussing fighter numbers and financial backing.
The revelations come amid growing instability in Syria’s coastal Alawite regions and rising sectarian tensions.
Leaked files detail plans for armed activity, highlighting the threat to national unity and fragile post-war recovery.

Al Jazeera’s Ali Hashem reports. 

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
Follow us on X: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish
Find us on Facebook:
title: Leaked calls reveal plot by al-Assad regime officers to destabilise Syria

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
For the first time in two months, a UN team entered Al-Fasher in Sudan’s Darfur region.
The paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) are accused of massacres after taking the city in October.
UN observers described Al-Fasher as a massive crime scene, suspecting a large RSF cleanup operation.
Hundreds of civilians remain, lacking food, medicine, and shelter, while more than 100,000 have fled.
Survivors recounted summary executions, sexual violence, and other systematic atrocities.
The UN could only conduct limited investigations under RSF supervision, with many detained or injured still inside.

Al Jazeera's Mohamed Vall reports from Kosti, in the White Nile State.
Renard Doussi from Solidarites International told Al Jazeera that the situation is worse than UN findings suggest.
Women and children make up the majority of those fleeing, facing extreme violence and prolonged displacement.
Eyewitness accounts describe killings, repeated sexual assaults, looting, and deliberate destruction o
title: UN says Sudan’s el-Fasher a ‘crime scene’ in first access since RSF capture

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Taiwan’s president has struck a defiant tone after China launched fresh military drills near the island.
In a New Year’s Day speech, Lai Ching-te said 2026 would be a critical year and vowed to defend Taiwan’s sovereignty.
He warned China aims to be ready to attack by 2027, though its success is uncertain.
Beijing responded by insisting Taiwan is part of China and independence is inevitable.
Taiwan is accelerating its military build-up and civilian defence training.
Lawmakers say preparations make a Chinese takeover difficult.
The drills highlight growing risks of rapid escalation in the Taiwan Strait.

Al Jazeera’s Zein Basravi reports from Taipei.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Yet again, Iran is facing another wave of public anger.
Thousands of Iranians have been protesting as a dire economic crisis takes a heavy toll on their daily livelihood.
From a sharp fall in the currency's value... to an unprecedented rise in inflation, Iran's economy has reached what many describe as a breaking point.
This time, the government has adopted a different approach as protests continue, calling for a dialogue mechanism.
But as the country reels from long-standing sanctions, what does the leadership have to offer?
And what would the consequences be if the protests escalate?

Presenter: James Bays

Guests: 

Ali Akbar Dareini - Researcher at Center for Strategic Studies. 

Marzie Khalilian - Political Analyst and Academic Researcher. 

Stephen Zunes - Professor of Politics and Founding Chair of Middle Eastern Studies at the University of San Francisco.

Follow us on X: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish

title: How far will the latest protests go in Iran? | Inside Story

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Several dozen people are presumed dead and about 100 have been injured after a blaze ripped through a crowded bar in the luxury Alpine ski resort town of Crans-Montana.
The fire started at about 1:30am (00:30 GMT) on Thursday morning in a bar called Le Constellation, as revellers rang in the new year, police spokesperson Gaetan Lathion said.
“Several dozen people are presumed to have died,” Frederic Gisler, the police commander in the Valais Canton in southwestern Switzerland, told reporters at a media briefing hours after the tragedy.
Beatrice Pilloud, attorney general of the Valais Canton, said it was too early to determine the fire’s cause but added that investigators have ruled out an attack.
Police said they could not immediately be more precise about how many people had been killed in the blaze. However, the Italian foreign ministry said in a statement that Swiss police believe about 40 people have died.
The resort is popular with tourists. Some of the victims are from ⁠other co
title: Switzerland: Dozens killed, 100 injured in bar blaze at ski resort town

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Rob Geist-Pinfold, a lecturer in international security at King’s College London, told Al Jazeera that integrating the Kurdish-led SDF into Syria’s army is critical to the country’s future stability.
He said what happens in eastern Syria will shape wider dynamics, with other minority groups closely watching the outcome.
Geist-Pinfold noted that neither Damascus, Turkiye nor the SDF wants escalation, but key issues remain unresolved after the integration deadline passed.
He explained Kurdish fears stem from past persecution and the high cost they paid fighting ISIL to secure autonomy.
The Syrian government wants full military integration, while the SDF seeks autonomy and to retain command structures.
He said a compromise could see Arab SDF units fold into the army, with Kurdish units retaining limited autonomy.
Geist-Pinfold added that sustained US mediation will be essential to break the current impasse.

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
Follow us on X: https://twit
title: Why Syria’s stalled SDF integration could reshape the country’s future: Analysis

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The EU is introducing a carbon border adjustment mechanism, a new tax targeting high-emission imports.
It mainly affects Chinese and Indian exports such as aluminium, cement, fertilisers and steel.
European leaders say the measure will cut pollution and push exporters to invest in cleaner technology.
It also aims to stop EU companies relocating to lower-cost countries and ensure fair competition.
The policy sends a message to major economies to meet EU environmental standards or risk market access.
However, it may raise prices for European consumers on goods like appliances and car parts.

Al Jazeera’s Hashem Ahelbarra reports from Brussels.

description:
We’re looking back at 10 of the episodes that defined 2025 at The Take. This originally aired on September 11. None of the dates or references have been changed.

Shot while answering a question about mass shootings, outspoken gun-rights advocate and conservative activist Charlie Kirk was killed on a university campus. What does this moment signal for escalating political violence and the state of US politics?

In this episode:

- Matthew Boedy, Professor of Rhetoric, University of North Georgia

Episode credits:

This episode was produced by Amy Walters, Sarí el-Khalili, Diana Ferrero and Tamara Khandaker, with Phillip Lanos, Spencer Cline, Melanie Marich, Chloe K. Li, Farhan Rafid, Kisaa Zehra, and our host, Malika Bilal. It was edited by Noor Wazwaz and Kylene Kiang. Special thanks to Negin Owliaei.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
An Israeli ban on dozens of international aid organisations operating in Gaza comes into force on Thursday, to coincide with the start of the new year.
UN agencies and other international aid groups are urging Israeli authorities to reverse the decision, warning it could undermine crucial lifesaving work in the strip.
Israel announced on Tuesday it will revoke the operating licenses of 37 aid groups that fail to meet new vetting rules, it says target Hamas’s exploitation of aid.
The UN and other international aid groups strongly reject that claim.
They say the ban will restrict critical assistance and put humanitarian workers at greater risk.

Al Jazeera’s Hani Mahmoud has the latest from Gaza City, Palestine.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Iran's president has called for solidarity as protests against soaring living costs spread across the country. 
In Fars province, security forces fired at protesters, while crowds tried to storm a local government building.
Authorities say at least one person has been killed in a western region.
Iran's chief prosecutor has warned of a “decisive” response if the protests threaten to destabilise the country.

The demonstrations began on Sunday after shopkeepers in Tehran's Grand Bazaar walked off the job.
Iranians are angry at the rapid decline of their currency, and a worsening economic situation. 
President Masoud Pezeshkian has appealed for unity. 
He says there is pressure coming from inside the country and from abroad.

Al Jazeera’s Tohid Asadi has more from Tehran, Iran.

title: Iran’s Pezeshkian urges unity as protests over economic woes turn deadly

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
2025 has been an unprecedented year for Israeli settlement expansion in the occupied West Bank. 
Israel has approved 41 illegal settlements and in the past three years it has forcibly taken one million parcels of land in the occupied territory. 
 
Al Jazeera’s Nida Ibrahim reports from the occupied West Bank, Palestine. 

Hamza Zubeidat is a land researcher in the occupied West Bank. 
He says Israel's illegal settlement expansion undermines any prospect for a two-state solution.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
A suicide attack in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo has killed a police officer. 
Local authorities say police were chasing an attacker who was trying to enter a Christian neighbourhood, when he detonated an explosive belt. 
The man was reportedly a member of ISIL who wanted to target a church.
At least two other people were injured. 
The bombing is the latest in a series of violent attacks that have challenged the government's efforts to unify the country. 

And the deadline for Kurdish SDF fighters to fully integrate into the Syrian army has now passed.
Syria says talks with the group have produced no tangible results.
Turkiye says that it backs Damascus if it chooses now to move against the Syrian Democratic forces.

Al Jazeera’s Resul Serdar has more from Damascus, Syria.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Thousands of people are rallying in Istanbul to protest the ongoing violence and humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
Demonstrators are marching from several major mosques, with all routes converging at the Galata Bridge, one of the city’s most iconic landmarks.

Al Jazeera's Sinem Koseoglu has more from Istanbul, Turkiye.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
People on the Indonesian island of Sumatra are still suffering from the devastating effects of widespread floods and landslides. 
It's been more than a month since torrential rains pounded the area.
Over a thousand people were killed and nearly 400,000 people are still displaced. 

Al Jazeera’s Jessica Washington reports from Aceh Tamiang, Indonesia.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The search for the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 resumed this week more than a decade after its disappearance. 
More than 200 people were on board, most of them Chinese nationals.
Their families have welcomed news of the renewed search hoping it will finally bring closure.

Al Jazeera’s Katrina Yu reports from Beijing, China.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Chinese President Xi Jinping has used his New Year's speech to vow that reunification with Taiwan will not be stopped. 
That comes after two days of military drills around the island. 
The exercises have triggered concern from the US, the EU, Australia and Japan. Beijing has rebuked any criticism. 
It claims democratically governed Taiwan as its own territory and has repeatedly warned against interference.
While Beijing ramps up pressure on Taipei, many young Taiwanese see themselves as distinct from China and reject unification especially by force.

Al Jazeera’s Zein Basravi reports from Taipei, Taiwan.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia has entered its sixth day. 
Al Jazeera has been given rare access to areas off-limits to Cambodian civilians, villages isolated behind barbed wire and military stations.
Assed Baig has seen Thai troops inside Cambodian territory and has been speaking to families who say they're being stopped from returning to their homes.
He filed this report from the Thailand-Cambodia border.
